Ponte Vecchio ;The Ponte Vecchio is a medieval stone closed-spandrel segmental arch bridge over the Arno
column2: in Florence
column3: Italy. The only bridge in Florence spared from destruction during World War II
column4: it is noted for the shops built along it; building shops on such bridges was once a common practice. Butchers
column5: tanners
column6: and farmers initially occupied the shops; the present tenants are jewellers
column7: art dealers
column8: and souvenir sellers.[3] The Ponte Vecchio's two neighbouring bridges are the Ponte Santa Trinita and the Ponte alle Grazie.  The bridge connects Via Por Santa Maria (Lungarno degli Acciaiuoli and Lungarno degli Archibusieri) to Via de' Guicciardini (Borgo San Jacopo and Via de' Bardi).  The name was given to what was the oldest Florentine bridge when the Ponte alla Carraia was built
column9: then called Ponte Nuovo in contrast to the old one. Beyond the historical value
column10: the bridge over time has played a central role in the city road system
column11: starting from when it connected the Roman Florentia with the Via Cassia Nova commissioned by the emperor Hadrian in 123 AD.  In contemporary times
column12: despite being closed to vehicular traffic

column14: Piazza della Signoria on one side with the area of Palazzo Pitti and Santo Spirito in the Oltrarno.  The bridge appears in the list drawn up in 1901 by the General Directorate of Antiquities and Fine Arts
column15: as a monumental building to be considered national artistic heritage. According to historians

column10: mimicking French boulevard design
column11: six lanes wide and lined with trees. On the left bank

Palazzo Vecchio ;The Palazzo Vecchio (Italian pronunciation: [paˈlattso ˈvɛkkjo] ""Old Palace"") is the town hall of Florence
column2: Italy. It overlooks the Piazza della Signoria

column1: Originally called the Palazzo della Signoria

column2: the commune and people of Florence decided to build a palace that would be worthy of the city's importance

column5: supported by small arches and corbels. Under the arches are a repeated series of nine painted coats of arms of the Florentine republic. Some of these arches can be used as embrasures (spiombati) for dropping heated liquids or rocks on invaders.

Giovanni Villani wrote that Arnolfo di Cambio incorporated the ancient tower of the Foraboschi family (the tower then known as ""La Vacca"" or ""The Cow"") into the new tower's facade as its substructure;[1] this is why the rectangular tower (height 94 m) is not directly centered in the building. This tower contains two small cells
column3: that

Galleria degli Uffizi;The Uffizi Gallery Italian: Galleria degli Uffizi
column2: pronounced is a prominent art museum located adjacent to the Piazza della Signoria in the district Santa Croce. One of the most important Italian museums and the most visited
column3: it is also one of the largest and best-known in the world and holds a collection of priceless works
column4: particularly from the period of the Italian Renaissance. T

column1: After the ruling House of Medici died out
column2: their art collections were given to the city of Florence under the famous Patto di famiglia negotiated by Anna Maria Luisa
column3: the last Medici heiress. The Uffizi is one of the first modern museums. The gallery had been open to visitors by request since the sixteenth century
column4: and in 1769 it was officially opened to the public
column5: formally becoming a museum in 1865.[4] The building of the Uffizi complex was begun by Giorgio Vasari in 1560 for Cosimo I de' Medici as a means to consolidate his administrative control of the various committees
column6: agencies
column7: and guilds established in Florence's Republican past so as to accommodate them all one place
column8: hence the name uffizi
column9: ""offices"". Instead of dark
column10: cramped and unhealthy spaces
column11: Vasari had created a spacious and luminous square. The style adopted is classical - Doric - which alludes to the fairness of the Prince's government. The construction was later continued by Alfonso Parigi and Bernardo Buontalenti; it was completed in 1581. The top floor was made into a gallery for the family and their guests and included their collection of Roman sculptures. The cortile (internal courtyard) is so long
column12: narrow
column13: and open to the Arno at its far end through a Doric screen that articulates the space without blocking it
column14: that architectural historians[6] treat it as the first regularized streetscape of Europe. Vasari
column17: emphasized its perspective length by adorning it with the matching facades' continuous roof cornices
column19: as well as the three continuous steps on which the museum fronts stand. The niches in the piers that alternate with columns of the Loggiato are filled with sculptures of famous artists in the 19th century.

column1: The Uffizi brought together under one roof the administrative offices and the Archivio di Stato
column2: the state archive. The project was intended to display prime artworks of the Medici collections on the piano nobile; the plan was carried out by his son
column3: Grand Duke Francesco I. He commissioned the architect Buontalenti to design the Tribuna degli Uffizi that would display a series of masterpieces in one room
column4: including jewels; it became a highly influential attraction of a Grand Tour. The octagonal room was completed in 1584.[7]

column2: their art collections were given to the city of Florence under the famous Patto di famiglia negotiated by Anna Maria Luisa
column3: the last Medici heiress.£ The Uffizi is one of the first modern museums.£ The gallery had been open to visitors by request since the sixteenth century
column4: and in 1769 it was officially opened to the public
column5: formally becoming a museum in 1865.£

column1: The building of the Uffizi complex was begun by Giorgio Vasari in 1560 for Cosimo I de' Medici as a means to consolidate his administrative control of the various committees
column2: agencies
column3: and guilds established in Florence's Republican past so as to accommodate them all in one place
column4: hence the name uffizi
column5: ""offices"".£ Instead of dark
column6: cramped
column7: and unhealthy spaces
column8: Vasari had created a spacious and luminous square.£ The style adopted is classical - Doric - which alludes to the fairness of the Prince's government.£ The construction was later continued by Alfonso Parigi and Bernardo Buontalenti; it was completed in 1581.£ The top floor was made into a gallery for the family and their guests and included their collection of Roman sculptures.£ The cortile (internal courtyard) is so long
column9: narrow
column10: and open to the Arno at its far end through a Doric screen that articulates the space without blocking it
column11: that architectural historians treat it as the first regularized streetscape of Europe.£ Vasari
column12: a painter and architect as well
column13: emphasized its perspective length by adorning it with the matching facades' continuous roof cornices and unbroken cornices between storeys
column14: as well as the three continuous steps on which the museum fronts stand.£ The niches in the piers that alternate with columns of the Loggiato are filled with sculptures of famous artists from the 19th century.£

column1: The Uffizi brought together under one roof the administrative offices and the Archivio di Stato
column2: the state archive.£ The project was intended to display prime artworks of the Medici collections on the piano nobile; the plan was carried out by his son
column3: Grand Duke Francesco I.£ He commissioned the architect Buontalenti to design the Tribuna degli Uffizi that would display a series of masterpieces in one room
column4: including jewels; it became a highly influential attraction of a Grand Tour.£ The octagonal room was completed in 1584.£

column1: Over the years
column2: more sections of the building were recruited to exhibit paintings and sculptures collected or commissioned by the Medici.£ For many years
column3: 45 to 50 rooms were used to display paintings from the 13th to 18th century.£

Basilica Santa Croce;The Basilica di Santa Croce (Italian for 'Basilica of the Holy Cross') is a minor basilica and the principal Franciscan church of Florence
column2: Italy. It is situated on the Piazza di Santa Croce
column3: about 800 metres southeast of the Duomo
column4: on what was once marshland beyond the city walls. Being the burial place of notable Italians
column5: including those from the Italian Renaissance such as Michelangelo
column6: Galileo
column7: and Machiavelli
column8: as well as the poet Foscolo
column9: political philosopher Gentile and the composer Rossini
column10: it is also known as the Temple of the Italian Glories (Tempio dell'Itale Glorie). The basilica is the largest Franciscan church in the world. Its most notable features are its sixteen chapels
column11: many of them decorated with frescoes by Giotto and his pupils
column12: [a] and its tombs and cenotaphs. Legend says that Santa Croce was founded by St Francis himself. The construction of the current church
column13: to replace an older building
column16: and paid for by some of the city's wealthiest families. It was consecrated in 1442 by Pope Eugene IV. The building's design reflects the austere approach of the Franciscans. The floorplan is an Egyptian or Tau cross (a symbol of St Francis)
column17: 115 metres in length with a nave and two aisles separated by lines of octagonal columns. To the south of the church was a convent
column18: some of whose buildings remain. The Basilica di Santa Croce is mixed style of gothic

column1: The Primo Chiostro
column2: the main cloister
column3: houses the Cappella dei Pazzi
column4: built as the chapter house
column5: completed in the 1470s. Filippo Brunelleschi (who had designed and executed the dome of the Duomo) was involved in its design which has remained rigorously simple and unadorned.

column2: the choir screen was removed as part of changes arising from the Counter-Reformation and the interior of this area was rebuilt by Giorgio Vasari. As a result
column3: there was damage to the church's decoration and most of the altars previously located on the screen were lost. The Bardi Chapel which contained a cycle of frescoes of the life of St Francis was plastered over
column4: at the behest of Cosimo I
column5: and Vasari placed some new altars against the walls
column6: causing considerable damage to the frescoes.[3]

column1: The bell tower was built in 1842
column2: replacing an earlier one damaged by lightning. The neo-Gothic marble façade dates from 1857 to 1863. The Jewish architect Niccolò Matas from Ancona designed the church's façade
column3: working a prominent Star of David into the composition. Matas had wanted to be buried with his peers but because he was Jewish
column4: he was buried under the threshold and honoured with an inscription.

column2: the complex became public property
column3: as a part of government suppression of most religious houses
column4: following the wars that gained Italian independence and unity.[4][5]

column1: Among the 19th-century restorations
column2: the 16th-century altars and plaster were removed from the Bardi Chapel
column3: revealing Giotto's frescoes of the Life of St Francis
column4: which include the Death of St. Francis. This painting
column5: missing sections where an altar had been attached to the wall
column6: was heavily restored in the 19th century. These restorations were later removed to reveal those areas which are definitively Giotto's
column7: leaving portions of the painting missing.[6]

column1: The Museo dell'Opera di Santa Croce is housed mainly in the refectory

column3: in the city in which she was born and after which she was named. Brunelleschi also built the inner cloister
column4: completed in 1453.

column2: during the safe hiding of various works during World War II
column3: Ugo Procacci noticed the Badia Polyptych being carried out of the church. He reasoned that this had been removed from the Badia Fiorentina during the Napoleonic occupation and accidentally re-installed in Santa Croce.[7] Between 1958 and 1961
column4: Leonetto Tintori removed layers of whitewash and overpaint from Giotto's Peruzzi Chapel scenes to reveal his original work.[1]

column2: the Arno River flooded much of Florence
column3: including Santa Croce. The water entered the church bringing mud
column4: pollution and heating oil. The damage to buildings and art treasures was severe
column5: taking several decades to repair.

Basilica di San Lorenzo;The Basilica di San Lorenzo (Basilica of St. Lawrence) is one of the largest churches of Florence
column2: Italy
column3: situated at the centre of the main market district of the city
column4: and it is the burial place of all the principal members of the Medici family from Cosimo il Vecchio to Cosimo III. It is one of several churches that claim to be the oldest in Florence
column5: having been consecrated in 393 AD
column6: [1] at which time it stood outside the city walls. For three hundred years it was the city's cathedral
column7: before the official seat of the bishop was transferred to Santa Reparata.

column1: San Lorenzo was the parish church of the Medici family. In 1419
column2: Giovanni di Bicci de' Medici offered to finance a new church to replace an eleventh-century Romanesque rebuilding. Filippo Brunelleschi
column3: the leading Renaissance architect of the first half of the fifteenth century
column4: was commissioned to design it
column5: but the building
column6: with alterations
column7: was not completed until after his death. The church is part of a larger monastic complex that contains other important architectural and artistic works: the Old Sacristy (""Sagresta Vecchia"") by Brunelleschi and having interior decoration and sculpture by Donatello; the Laurentian Library by Michelangelo; the Medici Chapels
column8: two structures that include the New Sacristy (""Sagrestia Nuova"") based on Michelangelo's designs; and the larger Cappella dei Principi (""Chapel of the Princes"") being a collaboration between the family and architects. The Basilica of San Lorenzo is considered a milestone in the development of Renaissance architecture. The basilica has a complicated building history. The project was begun around 1419
column9: under the direction of Filippo Brunelleschi. Lack of funds slowed the construction and forced changes to the original design. By the early 1440s
column10: only its sacristy (now called the Old Sacristy) had been worked on because that was being paid for by the Medici. In 1442
column11: the Medici stepped in to take over financial responsibility of the church as well. After Brunelleschi's death in 1446
column12: the job was handed either to Antonio Manetti or Michelozzo; scholars are uncertain which. Although the building was largely completed by 1459 in time for a visit to Florence by Pius II
column13: the chapels along the right-hand aisles were still under construction during the 1480s and 1490s.

column1: By the time the building was completed
column2: aspects of its layout and detailing no longer corresponded to the original plan. The principal difference is that Brunelleschi had envisioned the chapels along the side aisles to be deeper than those built and he intended them to resemble the chapels in the transept
column3: the only part of the building that is known to have been completed as Brunelleschi designed it.[2]";"The Basilica di San Lorenzo (Basilica of St. Lawrence) is one of the largest churches of Florence

Duomo di Firenze;Florence Cathedral (Italian: Duomo di Firenze)
column2: formally the Cathedral of Saint Mary of the Flower (Italian: Cattedrale di Santa Maria del Fiore [katteˈdraːle di ˈsanta maˈriːa del ˈfjoːre])
column3: is the cathedral of the Catholic Archdiocese of Florence. Commenced in 1296 in the Gothic style to a design of Arnolfo di Cambio and structurally completed by 1436 with the dome engineered by Filippo Brunelleschi;[1] the basilica's exterior is faced with polychrome marble panels in various shades of green and pink
column4: bordered by white
column5: and features an elaborate 19th-century Gothic Revival (west) façade by Emilio De Fabris.

column1: The cathedral complex
column2: in Piazza del Duomo
column3: includes the Baptistery and Giotto's Campanile
column4: it is present in the district San Giovanni. These three buildings are part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site covering the historic centre of Florence and are a major tourist attraction of Tuscany. The basilica is one of Italy's largest churches and its dome
column5: when first built back in the 15th century
column6: was the largest ever built in western Europe. Although it was later overtaken by St Peter's Basilica
column7: it still remains the largest dome ever constructed of bricks. The cathedral is the mother church of the Archdiocese of Florence
column8: whose archbishop is Gherardo Gambelli.[2] Santa Maria del Fiore was built on the site of Florence's second cathedral dedicated to Saint Reparata;[3] the first was the Basilica di San Lorenzo di Firenze
column9: the first building of which was consecrated as a church in 393 by St. Ambrose of Milan.[4] The ancient structure
column10: founded in the early 5th century and having undergone many repairs
column11: was crumbling with age
column12: according to the 14th-century Nuova Cronica of Giovanni Villani
column13: [5] and was no longer large enough to serve the growing population of the city.[5] Other major Tuscan cities had undertaken ambitious reconstructions of their cathedrals during the Late Medieval period
column14: such as Pisa and particularly Siena where the enormous proposed extensions were never completed.

column1: The city council approved Arnolfo di Cambio's design for the new church in 1294.[6] Di Cambio was also architect of the church of Santa Croce and the Palazzo Vecchio.[7][8] He designed three wide naves ending under the octagonal dome
column2: with the middle nave covering the area of Santa Reparata. The first stone was laid on 9 September 1296
column3: by Cardinal Valeriana
column4: the first papal legate ever sent to Florence. The building of this vast project was to last 140 years; Arnolfo's plan for the eastern end
column5: although maintained in concept
column6: was greatly expanded in size.

column1: After Arnolfo died in 1302
column2: work on the cathedral slowed for almost 50 years. When the relics of Saint Zenobius were discovered in 1330 in Santa Reparata
column3: the project gained a new impetus. In 1331
column4: the Arte della Lana
column5: the guild of wool merchants
column6: took over patronage for the construction of the cathedral and in 1334 appointed Giotto to oversee the work. Assisted by Andrea Pisano
column7: Giotto continued di Cambio's design. His major accomplishment was the building of the campanile. When Giotto died on 8 January 1337
column8: Andrea Pisano continued the building until work was halted due to the Black Death in 1348.

column2: as if completed

column4: painted in the 1360s

column2: action resumed on the cathedral under a series of architects
column3: starting with Francesco Talenti
column4: who finished the campanile and enlarged the overall project to include the apse and the side chapels. In 1359
column5: Talenti was succeeded by Giovanni di Lapo Ghini (1360–1369) who divided the centre nave in four square bays. Other architects were Alberto Arnoldi
column6: Giovanni d'Ambrogio
column7: Neri di Fioravanti and Andrea Orcagna. By 1375
column8: the old church Santa Reparata was pulled down. The nave was finished by 1380
column9: and only the dome remained incomplete until 1436.

column1: On 19 August 1418
column2: [9] the Arte della Lana announced an architectural design competition for erecting Neri's dome. The two main competitors were two master goldsmiths
column3: Lorenzo Ghiberti and Filippo Brunelleschi
column4: the latter of whom was supported by Cosimo de Medici. Ghiberti had been the winner of a competition for a pair of bronze doors for the Baptistery in 1401 and lifelong competition between the two remained sharp. Brunelleschi won and received the commission.[10]

column1: Ghiberti
column2: appointed coadjutor
column3: drew a salary equal to Brunelleschi's and
column4: though neither was awarded the announced prize of 200 florins
column5: was promised equal credit
column6: although he spent most of his time on other projects. When Brunelleschi became ill
column7: or feigned illness
column8: the project was briefly in the hands of Ghiberti. But Ghiberti soon had to admit that the whole project was beyond him. In 1423
column9: Brunelleschi was back in charge and took over sole responsibility.[11]

column1: Erection of the dome had begun in 1420 and was finished in 1436. The cathedral was consecrated by Pope Eugene IV on 25 March 1436
column2: the first day of the year according to the Florentine calendar. It was the first 'octagonal' dome in history to be built without a temporary wooden supporting frame. During the consecration in 1436
column3: Guillaume Dufay's motet Nuper rosarum flores was performed.

column1: The decoration of the exterior of the cathedral
column2: begun in the 14th century
column3: was left unfinished after the initial works done by Arnolfo di Cambio
column4: which led Lorenzo de' Medici to initiate a design competition for the façade between 1490 and 1491.[12] The competition went ultimately nowhere
column5: and the façade was not completed until 1887
column6: when the polychrome marble façade was completed with the design of Emilio De Fabris. The floor of the church was relaid in marble tiles in the 16th century.

column1: The exterior walls are faced in alternate vertical and horizontal bands of polychrome marble from Carrara (white)
column2: Prato (green)
column3: Siena (red)
column4: Lavenza and a few other places. These marble bands had to repeat the already existing bands on the walls of the earlier adjacent baptistery the Battistero di San Giovanni and Giotto's Bell Tower. There are two side doors: the Doors of the Canonici (south side) and the Door of the Mandorla (north side) with sculptures by Nanni di Banco
column5: Donatello
column6: and Jacopo della Quercia. The six side windows
column7: notable for their delicate tracery and ornaments
column8: are separated by pilasters. Only the four windows closest to the transept admit light; the other two are merely ornamental. The clerestory windows are round

column5: and the façade was not completed until 1887
column6: when the polychrome marble façade was completed with the design of Emilio De Fabris.£ The floor of the church was relaid in marble tiles in the 16th century.£

column1: The exterior walls are faced in alternate vertical and horizontal bands of polychrome marble from Carrara (white)
column2: Prato (green)
column3: Siena (red)
column4: Lavenza and a few other places.£ These marble bands had to repeat the already existing bands on the walls of the earlier adjacent baptistery
column5: the Battistero di San Giovanni
column6: and Giotto's Bell Tower.£ There are two side doors: the Doors of the Canonici (south side) and the Door of the Mandorla (north side) with sculptures by Nanni di Banco
column7: Donatello
column8: and Jacopo della Quercia.£ The six side windows
column9: notable for their delicate tracery and ornaments
column10: are separated by pilasters.£ Only the four windows closest to the transept admit light; the other two are merely ornamental.£ The clerestory windows are round
column11: a common feature in Italian Gothic.£

column1: Construction began in 1255. The palace was built to house first the Capitano del Popolo and later
column3: the 'podestà'
column4: the highest magistrate of the Florence City Council. This Palazzo del Podestà
column5: as it was originally called
column6: is the oldest public building in Florence. This austere crenellated building served as model for the construction of the Palazzo Vecchio. In 1574
column7: the Medici dispensed with the function of the Podestà and housed the bargello
column8: the police chief of Florence
column9: in this building
column10: hence its name.[1] It was employed as a prison; executions took place in the Bargello's yard until they were abolished by Grand Duke Peter Leopold in 1786
column11: but it remained the headquarters of the Florentine police until 1859. When Leopold II
column12: Holy Roman Emperor Peter Leopold was exiled
column13: the makeshift Governor of Tuscany decided that the Bargello should no longer be a jail
column14: and it then became a national museum.

column1: The original two-story structure was built alongside the Volognana Tower in 1256. The third storey
column2: which can be identified by the smaller blocks used to construct it
column3: was added after the fire of 1323. The building is designed around an open courtyard with an external staircase leading to the second floor. An open well is found in the centre of the courtyard.[1]
